customer_name: TURK HAVA YOLLARI A O TURKISH AIRLINES
customer_addr:
350 FIFTH AVENUE, SUITE 7510
NEW YORK, NY 10118
site_name: TURK HAVA YOLLARI AO TURKISH AIRLINES - IAD - Washington Dulles International Ai

citations.narrative:
Turkish Airlines could not provide health certificates for 6 German Shepherd puppies that arrive at Dulles International
Airport (IAD) on 05/30/24. An airline representative stated that they do not routinely keep copies of the health certificates
for dogs and cats transported as excess baggage.
Accepting carriers and intermediate handlers shall keep and maintain a copy of the health certificate for dogs and cats
transported and delivered in commerce. Turkish Airlines must keep a copy of the health certificate and maintain it for at
least a year in accordance with AWA Regulation Section 2.80 - Records, Disposition.

On 05/30/24, Officers for the Center of Disease Control (CDC) inspected a shipment of 6 German Shepherd puppies that
arrived on Turkish Airlines Flight TK007. One (1) German Shepherd puppy “Brenda” was deceased upon arrival. The
deceased puppy was in a crate with two (2) other puppies of similar weight and size that appeared healthy. There were
two empty bowls secured inside the crate. The CDC on-call veterinarian determined the puppy was dehydrated.
Animals should be handled in a manner that does not cause physical harm. Turkish Airlines must ensure animals are
handled in a manner that does not lead to physical harm during transit.

citations.desc: Primary enclosures used to transport live dogs and cats.
citations.narrative:
On 05/30/24, six (6) German shepherd puppies (DOB 1/28/24) arrived, as excess baggage, to Dulles International Airport
(IAD) on Turkish Airlines Flight #TK007 from Serbia. According to the Center for Disease Control (CDC) officers, there
were two (2) crates with three (3) dogs contained within each crate. There was inadequate space inside the primary
enclosure for for each of the three (3) puppies within the transport kennels to move around normally – stand, sit, and lie in
a natural position.
German shepherd puppies at 5 months of age weigh from 35lbs to 45lbs. No more than one live puppy 8 weeks to 6
months of age and weighing over 20 lbs., may be transported in the same primary enclosure when shipped via aircraft.
Turkish Airlines must ensure dogs are shipped in accordance with the regulations under subpart 3.15(e)(1) and 3.15(f).
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with airline representative.
n

narrative:
2.77(b) 
   
Records: Carriers and intermediate handlers. 
Turkish Airlines could not provide health certificates for 6 German Shepherd puppies that arrive at Dulles International 
Airport (IAD) on 05/30/24. An airline representative stated that they do not routinely keep copies of the health certificates 
for dogs and cats transported as excess baggage.  
 
Accepting carriers and intermediate handlers shall keep and maintain a copy of the health certificate for dogs and cats 
transported and delivered in commerce. Turkish Airlines must keep a copy of the health certificate and maintain it for at 
least a year in accordance with AWA Regulation Section 2.80 - Records, Disposition. 
2.131(b)(1)  Critical
   
Handling of animals. 
On 05/30/24, Officers for the Center of Disease Control (CDC) inspected a shipment of 6 German Shepherd puppies that 
arrived on Turkish Airlines Flight TK007. One (1) German Shepherd puppy “Brenda” was deceased upon arrival. The 
deceased puppy was in a crate with two (2) other puppies of similar weight and size that appeared healthy. There were 
two empty bowls secured inside the crate. The CDC on-call veterinarian determined the puppy was dehydrated.  
 
Animals should be handled in a manner that does not cause physical harm. Turkish Airlines must ensure animals are 
handled in a manner that does not lead to physical harm during transit. 
3.15(f)(3) 
   
Primary enclosures used to transport live dogs and cats. 
On 05/30/24, six (6) German shepherd puppies (DOB 1/28/24) arrived, as excess baggage, to Dulles International Airport 
(IAD) on Turkish Airlines Flight #TK007 from Serbia. According to the Center for Disease Control (CDC) officers, there 
were two (2) crates with three (3) dogs contained within each crate. There was inadequate space inside the primary 
enclosure for for each of the three (3) puppies within the transport kennels to move around normally – stand, sit, and lie in 
a natural position.

German shepherd puppies at 5 months of age weigh from 35lbs to 45lbs. No more than one live puppy 8 weeks to 6 
months of age and weighing over 20 lbs., may be transported in the same primary enclosure when shipped via aircraft. 
Turkish Airlines must ensure dogs are shipped in accordance with the regulations under subpart 3.15(e)(1) and 3.15(f). 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with airline representative.
